I want to add one correction to this video because it might be the only time I'll ever be in a position to correct anything you said haha.

Biological neurons actually are NOT binary. It is easy to think they are because the action potential itself is all or nothing. The professor who taught me always described it as flushing a toilet in that once it starts it can't stop. Because of that "all or nothing" aspect, they get described as binary, on/off signals. The issue though is single signals aren't how neurons transmit information.

The information transfer is actually a lot like artificial neural networks for most neurons. They fire at some rate within a range of rates which indicates a strength of something. Very similar to how artificial neurons hold some number between 0 and 1. Each neuron can fire very quickly or very slowly to indicate a range of values.

One clear example of how this affects you is with visual perception. Most of the receptors, as well as neurons in your cortex fire at some base rate which indicates no stimulation. If you stare at some color or a spinning wheel or really anything for a long time they will be firing at an increased rate and get fatigued. When you look away you will perceive an after image of the opposite colors or the opposite motion. What's really going on is those neurons are fatigued and no longer able to fire at the same rate or release the same levels of neurotransmitters as they normally do at the base rate. Your brain perceives this change as a "negative" of what you had been looking at making you see that illusion of the opposite colors or motion.

10:20 is not correct. Biological neurons do not function as On or Off. They, too, function off of thresholds and constant voltages. The neurons fires if an input pushes the voltage past a threshold. In the meantime, the neuron maintains fluctuating voltage through chemical reactions. Furthermore, if a neuron is triggered by multiple other neurons simultaneously, this provides an even greater response. Even more, the signals that neuron sends to other neurons depends on the size of the connections between neurons - one will pass more voltage than another.

While this neural network works well enough to be called a neural network, it is by no means related to a biological neural network, which functions based off repeated inputs past a threshold voltage triggering a neuron to grow a connection to its neighbor, and so on. Then pruning itself so that it functions more efficiently.

the problem with this approaches is that mathematicians don't understand that one single image has more information than just pixels. In order to perform real pattern recognition you must define what is the pattern first. For example, with letters and numbers it is important not just only see the final picture of the symbol but also recognize the process of writing those symbols, directions, speed and pressure. you must use several neural networks to extract different features from the input image. Then use those features together with the image itself as input for symbol recognition network. In short words, you have to recognize who wrote those symbols and how before recognizing symbols them selves. And better you define "who" better your networks will work. I am sure that your network will not work good if it can't recognize what writing instrument was used and on what surface. Graphology first, meaning after. Ok, why isn't the network designed to know what shape and relative position is?  The same shape should give the same activation (along with an encoding for postition) regardless of position as long as it's within the boundries. The same should go for size.  The same, within small limits, should go for rotation.  The encoding should understand that a shape can be made up of other shapes, with a given configuration of relative position at a relative scale.  Any recognition system that can't represent those generalities will obviously be brittle as hell. Now maybe you fake this by considering the output of the most decisive of N test on the same input, each version with an altered offset, size or rotation, or maybe that's the only way to fake that in, but this generality would seem to be necessary.

Some thoughts on the results:

1. 14:01 The weights for the first layer seem to be meaningless patterns when viewed individually, but combined, they do encode some kind of sophisticated pattern detection. That particular pattern detection isn't uniquely specified or constrained by this particular set of weights on the first layer; rather, there are infinitely many ways that the pattern detection scheme can be encoded in the weights of this single layer.

These infinite other solutions can be thought of as the set of matrices that are row-equivalent to the 16x700ish matrix where each row is the set of weights for each of the neurons on this layer. You can rewrite each of the rows as a linear combination of the set of current rows, while possibly still preserving the behavior of the whole NN by performing a related transformation to the weights of the next layer. In this way, you can rewrite the patterns of the first layer to try and find an arrangement that tells you something about the reasoning. 2. 15:10 I think I understand the reason why your NN produces a confident result - it's because it was never trained to understand what a number doesn't look like. When you feed random noise and get an answer from the network, it may seem it is nonsense. But in an experiment conducted in MIT few years back, people are shown thousands of noise images and asked whether an image felt like, say, a car. A simple yes/no answer. The subjects did not know why they made their choices, but they did anyway. Afterwards, when researchers take the average of all pixel values from all the images that participants say "yes, this reminds me of a car", they saw a vague, blur silhouette of a car. Same goes for other things. We don't identify cars by attributes of cars, we identify them by a representation of "carness" in our minds, which is statistically learned throughout years. Probably it's the same case with neural networks. It has a representation of fiveness and the random noise is statistically similar to it. You can google "Random Image Experiment Reveals The Building Blocks of Human Imagination" for further information on the experiment.

Biological neurons are only binary in the sense that firing is nearly all or nothing. The rest of the system is adjusted by various analog factors. Certain cytokines increase or reduce the firing threshold. This alters which signals can trigger and, quite importantly, how fast. Distance from the synapse junction adjusts the voltage effect of the ions released; The molecules themselves diffuse in threespace. Also, the refactory periods are not synchronized.

It would be much stranger if binary values worked to model a living network.

Now the thing I'm wondering is, when does a recurrent neural network arrive at an output vector? If nodes in a hidden layer can pass their values on to each other, then wouldn't it be possible for that to lead to some kind of infinite loop where neurons keep changing each other?* Or can it be assumed to always converge to a steady state of some sort, at which point the network rests? If so, would a programmed implementation just require a hardcoded check whether any node values are still changing? And if not, would the network be given a certain amount of time, be it measured in actual time or in a number of 'steps' (a step here being information being passed along from node to node once), after which point the network is forced to send its information forward only to the next layer/to the output layer?

(*) Not so much for what I think Wikipedia calls a finite impulse recurrent neural network, which only passes the information in a given layer forward in one direction (and so can also be represented in principle as a feedforward neural network, just possibly with very many hidden layers), but at least for an infinite impulse one, where nodes within a layer are connected in both directions so that you can get infinite loops of information, hence, I suppose, the name.

It looks to me that there's no easy way to calculate the gradient in this case. If gradient is something similar to derivative of a function, it can only be calculated analytically if the source function is more or less smooth. But here the source function is probably completely random. So to calculate a gradient in a point, you'll have to go brute force - i.e. calculate the value of the source function in lots of points in the vicinity of the given point, and then finding the max/min. Which doesn't seem to be very effective.

10:10 ANNs have continuously ranging activations like real neurons in that the value of the activation represents the activation frequency of the neuron over an arbitrary period of time. If a neuron were to spike 255 times in 255 time steps then its activation will be 255 using a linear or rectifier activation function. Given a sigmoid or something else, the activation will be somewhere near 1. In principle - 255 spikes over 255 steps = 255/255 = 1, whereas 128 spikes over 255 steps = 0.5, etc. Its all about the activation frequency of the neuron.

Really great that we have advanced this much with respect to programming. But one still wonders why we feel the need to call it Artificial "Intelligence" when there is no "intelligence" to be found.
Neither one of these two videos (the one explaining what neural networks are and this one) show any sign of intelligence and yet people persist on using language that makes it SEEM as if it is intelligent—such as by saying "and then it learns...".
You only have the ability to learn when you are conscious of your decision-making, until then it all comes down to programming.

We have natural programs such as flowers that do not "turn" towards the sun but are MADE to turn towards to the sun by the heat of the sun and its very own programming (or, what we call the seed). But the flower has no consciousness and therefore can not "choose" to do anything—hence why they are not considered intelligent.

Switch the flower with the machine, the sun with the human and the program with the genetic code of the seed and you will see how no machine is ever be intelligent until it possesses some level of consciousness—keep in mind that to be intelligent means to understand, which requires conscious decision-making.

PS: So either I am missing something here, or people are playing word-games by using semantics to redefine what the word "intelligent" means in order to make it seem as if machines can be artificially "intelligent" without actually being conscious.

Regarding "the pattern we might have hoped for," I have two questions. First, is it even reasonable to expect single isolated features? Consider the case where you train on a set of faces; You don't get individual features like an eye or a nose or a mouth, you get a set of eigen-faces. So are the resulting patterns some form of eigenfunctions, an orthogonal set of features that do actually capture small features but in a more nuanced way? Second question: suppose you preloaded the first weight matrix with the small features you hoped to get. When you do the multiplication of the input layer times these feature rows, the dot product is basically correlating the two vectors and should match the features if they are there. Given 784 weight rows, you can easily represent all the small features you want. It seems that that might work, right?
Oh, one more question: what is the relationship between the bias for a row and its mean? I suspect they are equal if the sigmoid (or ReLU) is going to split the data properly.

For the record, real neurons also have a 'gradient of activation'.

First, the 'input neurons' determine a certain 'value' for the neuron, which then sends a number of action potentials to the next neuron. The number of action potentials determine how much the neuron stimulates or inhibits the next neuron and the more stimulation a neuron receives as input the more action potentials are created that stimulate the next neuron.

In the research bit, you lost me, though. What is structured data?

When you train a network with randomly placed labels, in my understanding, you just tell it that "Genius" is called "Cow" and that is what it will recognize it is called. Changing the labels must mean that the cost function says "Cow" is the correct answer for "Genius". So, random labels with another meaning, like "Genius" is not always "Cow" but it can be any of the names, makes no sense: what would the cost function answer? Each time the distance from a different name-answer? I do not see any chance of learning or memorizing something meaningful in this.

What appears to be making a distinction between "memorizing" and "learning" what "Genius" looks like, makes some sense when the speed of successful training is measured in the 2nd study. But, why this faster achievement of successful training could occur is totally incomprehensible to me. But I have a feeling(!) that maybe the 1st study was somehow training the network in "not ascending" directions instead of in descending....

Further, I believe, what the network "learns" can only be related to the training process and while actual knowledge and learning would have to do with recognizing distinguishing attributes, among a set of such attributes and, thus, being able to also recognize when a new attribute should be registered, e.g., by not giving any answer!

Thus, sorry, but I am not at all convinced of what is presented as interesting research...

6:11 - I have become acutely aware that I learn best by performing a random walk on parameters and observing their effects on the world. For example, getting a malfunctioning door handle to click into place by jiggling it up and down or side to side while holding or pushing the lock at the right time.
I do this almost subconsciously but I see very few other people do this and rather most people seem to be oblivious to exploring their possibility space. In fact, its usually the first thing I try to do when analyzing a given problem. Explore the space of inputs and observe their effects and go with the one that has the greatest effect in the direction you want.
Another example is figuring out what a 1 year old wants. Try offering different things to him and observe his response. Also use clear gestures to reinforce communication such as point to a thing and say "Do you want this?". Over time you and the toddler will gain a mutual understanding.
But a lot of people when faced with a persistent problem never try anything new and just keep doing the same old thing that has proven ineffective.
Note that this strategy can be applied to any abstract problem or situation where you have parameters you can manipulate and observable effects. Of course not all problems are solvable, for example if you lack the ability to effect the system or observe the effects.
This also feels very much akin to control theory.

In this video, you assert that the biological brain deals in binary (10:19). That's not true. Every synapse has several receptors (pores) into which chemicals signals plug. Two main chemicals that direct this function are serotonin and dopamine (there are others). Each chemical opens, closes, pauses (slows), or outright blocks messages. The transmitter has output pores, and the receptor has input pores. The transmitter sends the chemical signals through the pores, and receptor accepts those "messages." There is a third mechanism that is often overlooked: it is the synaptic gap. It too functions to pass or impede messages. When the gap gets "crowded" with chemical messages, the chemical response between transmitter and receptor wanes: it gets "tired." A common chemical, caffeine, plays a role here. It opens up the synaptic gap, allowing more or sustained messaging despite the "crowdedness" of the synaptic gap. That is why when the caffeine wears off, the subject often gets a headache. Back to the transmitter/receptor/gap interfacing.
The transmitters sends chemical messages; the gap accumulates messages; and the receptor collects the messages. The transmitter sends different chemicals, and the receptor has receptor pores for each chemical. (Psychiatry works directly with this operation.) The receptor does not fire really; instead is it more like a tipping cup: flow begins, accelerates, then ebbs. There is no binary on/off. In fact because there are different message receptors the operation is far more complex in that the neuron distributes its messages based on the cumulation of specific or combined incoming messages. In other words, messages A and B may make the neuron act on A or B or AB or ABA or...

Hi! After watching this video twice, a little detail bugged me, and that is that "random noise" example you give, it popped out a lot of questions in me. And I want some "expert on the subject" to shine some light:

There's a TL;DR at the bottom!

In all the examples from which the NN learned, almost all of them had the outer layer's pixels set as 0.00, so that means that there are a lot of neurons that were 0 through the entire learning process. And how does this affect the network? well, correct me if i'm wrong, but no matter what weight relates those neurons, the output will still be zero . And this means that those weights are irrelevant to the cost function, meaning that they were never adjusted. This is terrible for the learning process because the biggest weights could indeed be the most irrelevant, AND totally random (if the biggest weight was assigned at the start to one of those neurons, when they were randomly chosen, that weight will almost never change throughout the entire learning process).

Considering that, when you feed a "random noise" image to the network, which if you look closely has an important activation on the outer layer , the layer that was never actually adjusted, those values will by random chance, affect the result much more than the ones near the center, which were narrowed down in the learning process.

How do you fix this? well, I could have started by mentioning this, but: The NN never actually learnt what isn't a number.

So TL;DR here: This is the question that I can't get out of my mind, I believe you could fix this not even touching the network's structure, you just feed it a bunch of examples of "random noise" and set the desired output to nothing at all. This will affect the cost function much more if the network is certain about any output, and even more important: the network will adjust every pixel of the input layer, and not only the ones near the center .

My belief is if you add those learning examples, you could even force this primitive network to search for more reasonable patterns. And get one that can also classify something as "not a number". So... is my belief correct?

As encouraged at the end I thought about it. About recognizing pieces of curve in first layers:
I have an interesting idea (I hope) which seems better than the expected idea (convolutionnal NN).
In convolutionnal NN we hardcode the neighborhood of neurons, but it seems this can be self taught by the data set. What, as human, we like to think as neighborhood is just the set of neurons for which the activation shows a statistical correlation. It just happens that looking space related things (like an image), this correlation is seen between points close to one another, but rather than hardcoding this last fact (introducing our understanding of space by declaring that only neurons close to one another should be melt into the same pixel of the next layer), we can let the more general fact (the statistical correlation) drives this neiborhood selection process. The neural network could make itself convolutionnal, based on this self taught neighborhood "consider only the neurons above a given threshold of correlation to the parent reference neuron of the previous layer".
Yes it wont necessarily perform better on our example, but it get rid of a supervised aspect, and the same system can adjust by itself to any kind of input (1D input, 2D input, 3D, ND inputs or even strange topology like hypertorus in 4D,) without any change because it deduces and build the topology of the data space based on statistical correlations from the input training data set
And large neural networks can start to form it's own training data and "learn" faster!

I like thinking of multi layered neural networks as sand dunes that interact with the input data (marble.) and this marble is a particle where it selectively acts with different "higgs fields" of different weights. "clustering" is a tendancy for marbles to follow the same track. multi layered neural nets is taking whatever grouped marbles arrive at the end and putting it through a fresh sand dune until they all follow different paths. the end goal is to put a marble down the hill, not have any fall off the tracks formed,  and each arrive at a conclusion of the track where it classifies things. We can put a known marble with a known answer down the hill so we know that for each marble that arrives on that particular track is the same as that known marble.  Each time you put a marble down this track you sprinkle  a layer of sand to reduce the erroneous tracks that form ( minimizing error function) but has the network has a problem with learning new things because it catastrophically forgets the first skill it learns.

I think about this a lot: the way to design a system to recognize things as an "unknown" but still quantifiable. Like knowing the difference between the numbers/letters, but also image noise, errors, smudges, and skews. Like to get a machine mind to "know" that half the number may have been covered or scratched off (i.e. to know that some mark is a number, but to also know it can't know if it was a 3 or an 8 because of another mark). (Not to mention the ultimate constant pareidolia that will result when the number finding system sees numbers in everything: branches clouds, etc.)

There will always be things outside the system of thought (cognition), and for the system to be robust it must know that there is outside the system of itself, and thus how and where to hand off processing. This will also help in the systems' own self correcting, as errant programs and systems will also create their own skewing of data and results, and the same system that can conceive of an exterior.

If we want AI to actually be intelligent it has to be able to step beyond itself, inventing and categorizing in ways that were previously unknown.

Some thoughts:

1. Does the cost function averaged over the training classes really correspond to the overall error? It might be better to compute the cost of each class, then use some heuristics to nudge the network (maybe limiting the nudge to only the neurons/weights involved in that decision).

2. Images that are "vaguely" a given number are not marked as such. They are labelled as "this is definitely number N". A better approach might be to associate a confidence with the image (e.g. this is somewhat like a 1, but is squiggly, so it could not be a 1).

3. Images that could be several numbers (e.g. looks like a 5, but is probably a 6) are not labelled as such. It would be better to label these with a confidence for each possible number. NOTE: This also applies to areas like part of speech, where a part of speech label could be ambiguous (e.g. "Reading through the ages." -- noun (town) or verb?).

4. Accounting for a "this is not a number" output, and adding appropriate training data is not considered.

5. Real brains are more complicated, with many more layers, with connections across layers, and with things like image perception processing two sets of visual data in an interleaved pattern. As such, how do other models perform?

6. Real learning is not a single "learn to recognise all these images of numbers until you get them right" approach, but is an interactive feedback loop over years, and is a continual approach. How can this be applied to ANNs, and does it help with ANNs?

First of all, I love your videos (and podcast)! :) As always, you have great animations that really support the understanding!
Secondly, I think your side note on biological neurons is not entirely correct. It is true, that if a neuron "fires", i.e. emits an action potential (AP), the amplitude of the electrical signal will always be the same (so basically no amplitude = 0, high amplitude = 1). However, by changing the frequency or firing rate of emitting these action potentials (basically the rate of emitting 1's and 0's), different stimulus intensities can be encoded (more frequent APs correspond to a higher intensity stimulus, less frequent APs correspond to a lower intensity stimulus). I would therefore argue that the "activation" of a biological neuron is also continuous and not necessarily binary.
Of course this has nothing to do with the content of the actual video, which is a really good (and intuitive) explanation on Gradient Descent (way more intuitive than when I learned that in university :D).
